thread.title: RPI hockey falls to Michigan
thread.title_full: RPI hockey falls to Michigan - Times Union

author: Matt Graves
title: RPI hockey falls to Michigan
text:
Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI Image 1 of / 1 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 1 Buy photo RPI's Jason Kasdorf makes a save during their game against Boston College on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union) RPI's Jason Kasdorf makes a save during their game against Boston College on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union) Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI Buy this photo RPI hockey falls to Michigan 1 / 1 Back to Gallery Troy
A three-game losing streak isn't exactly the way RPI wanted to head into next weekend's critical home-and-home series with arch-rival Union to open the ECAC Hockey season.
But that's the way it will be after 11th-ranked Michigan skated off with a 5-2 victory over RPI in front of a sellout crowd of 4,646 Saturday night at Houston Field House . RPI drops to 1-4-0, its lone win coming against top-ranked Boston College on Oct. 11.
Playing with 10 NHL draftees, Michigan got a pair of goals from Tyler Motte and Brendan Warren and scored three times in the final period to improve to 3-0-1.
More Information
MICHIGAN 5, RPI 2
Michigan 1 2 2 — 5
RPI 0 1 1 — 2
First period— 1, Michigan, Warren 1 (Marody, Martin) 2:40. Penalties— Warren, Mic (hooking) 16:52.
Second period— 2, Michigan, Motte 3 (Kile) 0:28. 3, RPI, Schroeder 1 (Fulton, Reno) 5:03. 4, Michigan, Calderone 2 (Cecconi) 15:11. Penalties— Downing, Mic (boarding) 6:37; Wilson, RPI (slashing) 15:11.
Third period— 5, RPI, Wood (Liljegren, Prapavessis) 12:27 (pp). 6, Michigan, Warren 2 (Calderone. Marody) 17:04. 7, Michigan, Motte 4 (Selman, Connor) 18:26. Penalties— Compher, Mic (roughing) 2:28; Ohrvall, RPI (roughing) 2:28; Moore, RPI (tripping) 4:03; Cecconi, Mic (holding) 10:54; Tironese, RPI, major (Misconduct) 17:04.
Shots on goal— Michigan 6-11-11—28; RPI 4-7-10—21.
Power-plays— Michigan 0 of 2; RPI 1 of 3.
Goalies— Michigan, Nagelvoort 2-0-0 (21 shots-19 saves). RPI, Kasdorf 1-4-0 (27-23).
T— 2:15. A— 4,646.
"I thought we were a little tentative in the first period," RPI coach Seth Appert said. "We made a few big mistakes; we didn't make a ton of mistakes and we didn't give up a ton of chances. Our turnovers and our mistakes are a little bigger when you're playing a team of their skill level."
Michigan wasted little time getting the scoring under way, with Warren, a freshman, putting a wrister past RPI goalie Jason Kasdorf only 2:40 into the game from the left slot to give the Wolverines the first-period lead.
It took even less time starting the second period for the Wolverines to double their advantage. Motte scored on his stomach sliding across the right goal line when he pushed the puck just inside the left goal post only 28 seconds into the period. It was a goal both Appert and Kasdorf admitted shouldn't have been scored.
"There's a couple I would have liked back," Kasdorf said. "I should have been off the post. I should have been involved. It would have been a simple save."
But RPI cut the Michigan lead in half when Zach Schroeder buried a rebound from just outside the crease at 5:03 after shots by Travis Fulton and Parker Reno were stopped.
Michigan made it 3-1 at 15:11 on a wrister by Tony Calderone from the left circle and after Jake Wood scored on a power play with a great individual drive to the net at 12:27 of the final period, RPI was back in the game.
Less than five minutes later, Warren scored again on a tipped shot from outside, then the Wolverines put it away with an empty-net goal from Motte at 18:26.
"We're trying to learn our lessons and fix our mistakes," said Wood, who scored his second goal of the season. "We're working on those things and trying to get better every game."
The victory was Michigan's third in two seasons against the Engineers, having swept RPI in Ann Arbor last season. Michigan played Union to a 5-5 tie on Friday night in Schenectady.
"These were two tough teams," said Michigan coach Red Berenson . "I really thought our team took it from them tonight. They (RPI) just couldn't get back in the game."
Matt Graves is a freelance writer.
